embed.title: Community Tested Routers
embed.description:
The following routers have been reported to work reliably from a number of users.
High End (AXE / WiFi 6E) - TP-Link AXE300/AXE16000 ($450 US)
High End (AX / WiFi 6) - Asus RT-AX86U ($300 US)
Dedicated (BE / Wifi 7) - TP-Link BE9300/BE550 ($200-$300 US)
Dedicated (AXE / WiFi 6E) - Davolink 'Kevin' Minion 6E ($129 US)
Dedicated (AXE / WiFi 6E) - TP-Link Archer AXE75/AXE5400 ($160-$200 US)
Dedicated (AX) - PRISMXR Puppis S1 (80$)
Dedicated (AX / WiFi 6) - GL.iNet Beryl GL-MT3000 ($90 US)
Low End (AC / WiFi 5) - GL.iNet Opal GL-SFT1200 ($50 US)
Low End (AC / WiFi 5) - TP-Link Archer C6 or A6 ($40 US)

TP-Link AX and Huawei routers have been known to have issues we are unable to identify. Higher end TP-Link AX/AXE routers not listed here may work well but as with any router not on this list, should be considered untested.
The TP-Link Archer AXE5400 is not the same thing as the Deco AXE5400. The latter is a mesh router and may not work as expected.

name: iobt
description: Information about IOBT and Forwarded Data

embed.title: Inside Out Body Tracking
embed.description: Virtual Desktop supports passing through upper body tracking (Q3) and estimation using Meta IOBT (All Quests).

fields.name: What is IOBT?
fields.value: Inside out Body Tracking is a [feature provided by Meta](https://developer.oculus.com/blog/inside-out-body-tracking-and-generative-legs/) that allows you to use the Quest for Full Body Tracking/Estimation.

fields.name: Supported Devices
fields.value: All Quest devices are supported, at this time no other devices have this feature available on native openXR.

fields.name: What is Tracked on IOBT?
fields.value:
**Quest 3**: Upper Body is tracked using the cameras, waist and legs are estimated based on upper body positioning.
 **Quest 2/Pro/1**: All estimation based on head and hand pose. Cameras do not track your body. [You can see a demo of estimation here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lkDW5yuQnvQ)

fields.name: Are my feet tracked?
fields.value: Meta does not provide feet tracking, only feet estimation based on upper body pose.

fields.name: Can I use this with other trackers?
fields.value:
Yes, you can disable specific trackers at any time by setting the individual tracker to 'Held In Hand' or using [Dentech's configuration tool](https://github.com/DenTechs/Virtual_Desktop_Body_Tracking_Configurator/releases).
 This will allow you to use Slime/Vive trackers with IOBT.

fields.name: Hand Tracking/Body Tracking not showing up in SteamVR
fields.value:
Verify the 'Vive Tracker Emulation' is enabled in the VD Streaming tab which is an option once 'Forward Tracking Data to PC' is enabled.

 Once enabled, verify SteamVR Addons has the Virtual Desktop addon enabled.

embed.title: Valve Index Controller Emulation
embed.description: Virtual Desktop allows you to emulate Index Controllers for full hand tracking support, as well as Skeletal Input in SteamVR.

fields.name: Where can I use it?
fields.value: Not all games will support it, but in supported games in scenes that do not require buttons such as stationary VRChat.

fields.name: How do I use it?
fields.value:
Make sure Hand Tracking is enabled in the Quest in 'Movement Tracking'
 Enable Forward Data to PC in the 'Streaming' Tab in Virtual Desktop

Skeletal Input: No other changes, this will pass through as expected.
Regular Hand Tracking: Check 'Index Controller Emulation'.

fields.name: What is Tracked on Index Controller Emulation?
fields.value:
On all Quests, you can pass through your hand tracking as index controller emulation, allowing you to use full finger movement on hand tracking in supported games.

 If the game supports Skeletal Input, you do not need to enable this option and will have full Skeletal including Splay in supported titles.

fields.name: It's not working?
fields.value: Make sure the SteamVR Addon for Virtual Desktop is enabled, if disabled this will not work as expected.

fields.name: How do I move?
fields.value: While using hand tracking, you cannot move however you can pick up a controller at any time for movement.

embed.title: Opal Setup Guide
embed.description: You can follow a video guide on how to setup your Opal [here](https://youtu.be/1HwT-Own6vo).

embeds.title: Introduction
embeds.description:
The following chain of messages is a setup guide specifically designed for owners of the GL.iNet Opal router (model GL-SFT1200) with no way to directly wire it to both their PC and home router as an access point for Virtual Desktop, you can follow a video guide on how to setup your Opal [here](https://youtu.be/1HwT-Own6vo) as well. Traditionally, network bridges for Virtual Desktop are set up by using Internet Connection Sharing on Windows to feed Internet to a router in Access Point mode by the WAN port. The Opal can repeat an Internet connection wirelessly while transmitting its own Wi-Fi signal, as shown in the !opalsetup diagram drawn by @DenTechs.

In this guide, we will set up the GL.iNet Opal to use Repeater Mode, which takes your existing home Wi-Fi connection and repeats it to your PC over Ethernet and your VR headset over its own Wi-Fi signal. This means the Opal router will be able take video data from your PC by Ethernet and send it over Wi-Fi to your VR headset, while also providing an Internet connection to each device. This is both less expensive and more versatile than the D-Link AirBridge solution. The setup process is very easy and should take no longer than 20 minutes to complete.

fields.name: Requirements
fields.value:
- [GL.iNet Opal](https://www.amazon.com/GL-iNet-GL-SFT1200-Secure-Travel-Router/dp/B09N72FMH5)
- Ethernet Cable
- VR Ready PC with Virtual Desktop Streamer installed
- VR Headset with Virtual Desktop installed
- Your current home router (2.4GHz sufficient. Internet speed irrelevant)

fields.name: Note
fields.value:
The Opal includes a very short Ethernet cable. For best results, use a long cable to clear the router of other electronics.

Owners of the GL.iNet Slate AX (model GL-AXT1800) and Opal owners using the experimental GL.iNet firmware v4 from the firmware download page may use this guide, as the UI and functionality are very similar, with the exception of channel optimization.

fields.name: Caution
fields.value: Always use the included power brick or equivalent. The Opal's power input spec is 5V/3A.

pages.name: SetupWifi
pages.title: Set up your new GL.iNet Opal Wi-Fi network.
pages.description: If you have already set up your GL.iNet Opal, please review steps 4-5.

embeds.title: Set up your new GL.iNet Opal Wi-Fi network.
embeds.description: If you have already set up your GL.iNet Opal, please review steps 4-5.

fields.name: Step 1
fields.value: Power up your GL.iNet Opal and connect your PCs Ethernet cable to one of the LAN ports. Avoid using the WAN port during setup.

fields.name: Step 2
fields.value: In your browser URL bar, enter 192.168.8.1 to access the GL.iNet Admin Panel. This is the router's LOCAL IP address; no one can access it from outside your network.

fields.name: Step 3
fields.value: If you have not done so, perform first-time setup and set the admin password. You may want to write this down, as you will need to enter it every time you access the Admin Panel from now on. This password can be changed later without impacting connected devices.

fields.name: Step 4
fields.value: Go to the Wireless tab. From here, you can set up the Wi-Fi name and password for your VR headset to connect to. Perform the next set of steps for both the 2.4G and 5G networks.

fields.name: Step 5
fields.value:
On both networks, click Channel Optimization and wait for it to complete. The router will scan Wi-Fi channels in your area and select the least congested one.

Make sure Guest Networks are disabled, as they may cause issues for Virtual Desktop if enabled.

pages.name: ConnectToInternet
pages.title: Connect your GL.iNet Opal to the Internet.
pages.description: Connect your GL.iNet Opal to the Internet.

embeds.title: Phase 2: Connect your GL.iNet Opal to the Internet.
embeds.description: In this phase, we will connect your GL.iNet Opal to the Internet.

fields.name: Step 1
fields.value: Set up Repeater Mode.

fields.name: Step 2
fields.value: Set up Extender Mode (optional, but recommended if you find the Internet connection is a bit slow or you need your PC to see other devices on the home network.)

pages.name: ConnectVRToOpal
pages.title: Connect your VR Headset to the GL.iNet Opal.
pages.description: Connect your VR headset to the GL.iNet Opal.

embeds.title: Phase 3: Connect your VR Headset to the GL.iNet Opal.
embeds.description: In this phase, we will connect your VR headset to the GL.iNet Opal.

fields.name: Step 1
fields.value: Connect your VR headset to your new Wi-Fi.

fields.name: Step 2
fields.value: Open Virtual Desktop.

fields.name: Step 3
fields.value: Launch a game.

pages.name: notes
pages.title: Notes and Miscellaneous Information
pages.description: Additional information and notes for the setup process.

embeds.title: Phase 1 Notes
embeds.description:
You can disable the 2.4GHz network if you wish, by turning it off in the Wireless tab, but any time you perform a router reset, it will turn on again. All GL.iNet Opal routers have the same default Wi-Fi passwords, which is why Step 4e is required. Fortunately, router resets do not revert your passwords or network names.

Turning down the TX Power of your Opal Wi-Fi will reduce the range at which your devices can connect to it. While this may seem counterintuitive, it may be a courteous gesture to do so, as your neighbors will have less wireless interference. However, do this at your own risk. It may slow your connection down.

Do not use the guest networks on the GL.iNet Opal if you plan to use Virtual Desktop. Having guest networks enabled is unnecessary and can lead to problems connecting or using VR. This does not apply to the Opal exclusively; guest networks should be avoided generally for Virtual Desktop.

embeds.title: Phase 2 Notes
embeds.description:
Soft Reset: If you experience a problem (lose Internet, can no longer connect to your GL.iNet Wi-Fi or lose access to the admin panel), hold the button on the side of the router for 4 seconds. The light will slowly blink blue 3 times. Let go as soon as it starts to blink faster. If the light stays solid while holding the button, leave the router alone for 5 minutes, as it may be recovering from a crash. Avoid unplugging the router until you have access to the admin panel. This soft reset will restore access to the admin panel and re-enable your Wi-Fi, but you will need to reconnect Repeater Mode.

?? CAUTION: Do not hold the reset button for longer than the suggested time, as a 10 second hold WILL cause a FACTORY RESET!

When this guide was originally written, it was thought that Repeater Mode was too slow to be used for VR and that connecting the GL.iNet router to the home Wi-Fi over 5GHz would cause Virtual Desktop to underperform. This is no longer the case. Testing has proven that Repeater Mode can handle VR just fine and using 5GHz may actually be beneficial in some situations. Depending on your situation, it may even give your PC full speed Internet.

Choosing Extender Mode may be helpful if you need to use local connections with other devices.

embeds.title: Phase 3 Notes
embeds.description:
While it is absolutely not required, it may help to tell your headset to treat the Wi-Fi connection as unmetered. There have been no confirmed cases (to my knowledge) of this actually helping or solving any particular issue, but it is something to keep in mind.

Sometimes you may see an orange warning when Virtual Desktop connects, even if nothing is wrong. Ive seen this happen frequently after making changes to my router. If it fails to connect after two or three attempts, restart your PC and headset. If it fails again, restart the router by disconnecting it from power for 10 seconds.

embed.title: General Minimum Specs for VR
embed.description:
OS: Windows 10
CPU: Intel i5-7500 / AMD Ryzen 5 1600 or greater
RAM: 12GB+ RAM
GPU: NVIDIA GTX 1660 Super / AMD Radeon RX 5600XT or greater
USB Ports: 1x 3.1 port
Free Space: 35GB on C:

fields.name: Detailed Info
fields.value:
You can find detailed minimums below. Please note that minimum does not mean you can play every game.
[Oculus Rift S Supported Specs](https://store.facebook.com/help/quest/articles/getting-started/getting-started-with-rift/rift-s-minimum-requirements/)
[Oculus Link Supported Specs](https://store.facebook.com/help/quest/articles/headsets-and-accessories/oculus-link/oculus-link-compatibility/)
[Valve Index Supported Specs](https://support.steampowered.com/kb_article.php?ref=4061-QUZB-4602)

embed.title: Reinstall Visual C++ Redistributable
embed.description:
If you're experiencing issues launching SteamVR, reinstalling the Visual C++ Redistributable might help. Follow these steps:

1. Download the Visual C++ Redistributable from [this link](https://aka.ms/vs/17/release/vc_redist.x86.exe).
2. Close SteamVR and the Virtual Desktop Streamer if they're running.
3. Run the downloaded installer and follow the prompts to install.
4. Restart your computer after the installation is complete.
5. Try launching SteamVR again.

If the issue persists, please provide more details about the specific error you're encountering.

embed.title: Play Roblox in VR
embed.description:
1. Set SteamVR as default OpenXR Runtime.
2. Launch SteamVR from the button in the Virtual Desktop menu in VR.
3. Switch back to desktop and Launch Roblox.
4. Toggle VR mode in Roblox.

footer.text: Please note, Robloxs VR support is quite buggy.

name: previous
description: How to Install the Previous Version

embed.title: How to Install the Previous Version
embed.description: If you suspect that a newer version is causing issues, you can install the previous version at any time by uninstalling the current version from your device and following the instructions below.

fields.name: **Quest**
fields.value:
Download the previous version using the [Release Channel](https://vrdiscord.com/screenshots/vd/releasechannel/release.jpg) option to choose 'Previous' within your Quest by clicking the [three dots](https://vrdiscord.com/screenshots/vd/releasechannel/apps.jpg) and selecting [settings](https://vrdiscord.com/screenshots/vd/releasechannel/settings.jpg).
 Download the previous Streamer from [GitHub](https://github.com/guygodin/VirtualDesktop/releases/) for the version you are installing.

fields.name: **Pico**
fields.value: Download the previous version APK and Streamer from [GitHub](https://github.com/guygodin/VirtualDesktop/releases/) for the version you are installing. Copy the APK to your Pico or download using the browser and install with File Browser, and reinstall the correct streamer.

embed.title: Recommended GPU Drivers
embed.description:
Nvidia RTX 30/40 Series: [566.36](https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/geforce/drivers/results/237719/)

Nvidia: [Latest](https://www.nvidia.com/en-us/software/nvidia-app/)

AMD RX 400/500/VEGA series: [20.10.1](https://www.guru3d.com/download/amd-radeon-adrenalin-edition-20-10-1-driver-download/) (newer versions can have HEVC crashing issues)

AMD 5000/6000/7000/9000 series: [25.3.1](https://www.amd.com/en/resources/support-articles/release-notes/RN-RAD-WIN-25-3-1.html)

embed.title: Ethernet Connection Required
embed.description: Virtual Desktop requires a Gigabit Ethernet connection from your PC to your router. This is required for support.

fields.name: **Connection Requirements**
fields.value:
• Gigabit Ethernet from PC to router
• AC or AX router

Wireless PC connections cause instability and are NOT supported, even if they worked temporarily in the past.

fields.name: **Router Too Far?**
fields.value: Check `/routers` for a list of tested dedicated streaming routers that can be placed closer to your play space.

embed.title: VoiceMeeter Mode
embed.description:
**VoiceMeeter Mode** (with VR Headset only selected) restricts audio reaching the headset to only the Virtual Desktop Audio device. The Virtual Desktop Audio device can then be used in a software app such as VB Audio's VoiceMeeter for routing audio directly to the headset.

This mode does not perform any other function. The best place for support with VoiceMeeter is [VB Audio's Discord server](https://discord.com/invite/TF42rahAXS).

embed.title: Ethernet is required
embed.description: Rebooting your router can provide a temporary fix for certain issues you may be experiencing. Please note that since 2018, a Gigabit Ethernet connection between your PC and an AC or AX router is mandatory for support. Past success with other setups does not guarantee stability, and these configurations are not supported due to frequent complications. If your router is too far away to establish an Ethernet connection, use the command '/routers' to view a list of dedicated routers that have been tested by the community.

name: remote
description: Connecting to your computer remotely over the internet

embed.title: Connecting to your computer remotely over the internet
embed.description:
Make sure 'Allow remote connections' is checked in the Streamer window, Options tab on your computer.

You'll also need to enable UPnP on your router and the Streamer App will forward the required ports automatically.

If you want to manually configure your router, forward TCP ports 38810, 38820, 38830 and 38840. All traffic uses end-to-end encryption.

embed.title: Don't ask to ask; just ask
embed.description: Asking 'Hey, can anyone help me?' can be seen as bad form. The best way to get assistance is to ask your entire question, with all the necessary details, in a relevant channel. There are many reasons why knowledgeable people might not offer help upfront, but by asking the full question, you're inviting people to provide an answer, not asking them to commit to solving a problem they might not know how to solve.

embed.title: Uninstall and Reinstall GPU Drivers
embed.description:
Follow these steps to uninstall GPU drivers using DDU (Display Driver Uninstaller):
1. Download DDU from the [official website](https://www.guru3d.com/files-details/display-driver-uninstaller-download.html) and download the GPU driver you intend to install (see below).
2. Reboot your PC into [Safe Mode](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/start-your-pc-in-safe-mode-in-windows-92c27cff-db89-8644-1ce4-b3e5e56fe234)
3. Launch DDU and select the GPU from the list.
4. Click on 'Clean and restart'.
5. After the process and restart, the GPU drivers will be uninstalled.

You can then reinstall the reccomended drivers, to check the latest recommendations type /drivers.

embed.title: Internet isn't used when streaming
embed.description: Once your VR headset is connected to your computer, all data traffic remains local. This is true whether you're connected directly to your main router or to a dedicated router on the same local area network (LAN). The only requirement is a wired connection from your PC to a router. The VR headset then connects wirelessly to the same router or dedicated router.

embed.title: PUA
embed.description:
Microsoft's Windows Defender includes a feature called 'Potentially Unwanted App (PUA) Protection' or 'Reputation-based Protection'. This can sometimes flag new installers incorrectly. To disable it:

1. Open your Start menu
2. Type 'reputation'
3. Click on 'Reputation-based Protection' (should be the top result)
4. Scroll down to 'Potentially Unwanted App Blocking'
5. Turn this setting off.

embed.title: App Recommendation Settings
embed.description:
To bypass Microsoft's restrictive app installation policy:

1. Open Start menu
2. Search 'Choose where to get apps'
3. In 'Apps & features', set to 'Anywhere'

This allows installing apps from any source. You may still see warnings, but can select 'Install anyway'.

name: wifi
description: Wi-Fi link speed doesn't mean actual data speed

embed.title: Wi-Fi link speed doesn't mean actual data speed
embed.description:
Think of Wi-Fi link speed as a pipe's size and data as water. The link speed is the maximum water that can flow through the pipe. However, the actual flow can be slower due to several reasons: 
1. Shared bandwidth - it's like too many taps drawing water from the same pipe, slowing down the flow at each tap. 
2. Interference - it's like dirt in the pipe blocking the flow of water. Other devices can interfere with your Wi-Fi signal. 
3. Distance and obstacles - it's like the pipe being longer or having turns, slowing down the water. Being further from the router or having walls in between can slow down your Wi-Fi. 
So, a big pipe (high link speed) doesn't always mean fast water flow (high data speed).

name: ptc
description: Opting Out of Public Test Channel (PTC)

embed.title: PTC
embed.description:
Here's how you can opt-out of the Public Test Channel (PTC):

1. Open your Quest mobile app on your phone.
2. Go to 'Devices', then 'Headset Settings', and then 'Advanced Settings'.
3. If 'Public Test Channel' is enabled, click on it to disable.

Remember, it's usually better to avoid opting in for public test versions unless you're ready to deal with potential bugs. While these test builds can have exciting new features, they can also have unresolved issues, sometimes even game-breaking ones.

embed.title: Limitations
embed.description:
Virtual Desktop does not stop or hinder you from using it with a network or PC setup that does not meet minimum requirements. Also, not meeting the minimum requirements doesn't necessarily mean that VRD or your game won't work.
However, because VRD wasn't designed to work on setups that don't meet the requirements, we can't actively support those setups and we cannot guarantee the app will work.

embed.title: Internet Connection Sharing
embed.description:
If you're uncertain about how to set up Internet Connection Sharing, you can follow the instructions provided in [this guide](https://github.com/Crayphish/vrdocs/wiki/Internet-Connection-Sharing)

If you have issues with ICS not working after a computer restart (even after applying the registry fix), you can try [this script](https://discord.com/channels/564087419918483486/692030889932095529/1178882282229075978)

embed.title: Automatic Bitrate
embed.description: Automatic Bitrate conducts a small 10MB speed test when you first connect to determine your maximum stable bitrate. While it can be disabled in the VRD Streamer in the Options tab, we recommend leaving it on in order to help in detecting network issues.

embed.title: Test for a double NAT
embed.description: The simplest way to test for a double NAT is to check the IP assigned to WAN on your router and compare it to the result when you Google "what is my IP". If they are not the same, that means you have a double NAT. Another, less reliable, method is to open a command prompt on a computer in your home and type: tracert 8.8.8.8. If you see multiple private IP addresses, it means you have a double NAT. For more information, visit: https://windowsreport.com/double-nat/

name: oculusgo
description: Streamer Version for Oculus Go & GearVR Users

embed.title: Streamer Version for Oculus Go & GearVR
embed.description: If you're using Oculus Go or GearVR, you need to use version 1.20.38 of the Streamer. This is the last version that is compatible with these devices. You can download it from [here](https://download.vrdesktop.net/files/go/VirtualDesktop.Streamer.Setup.exe).

embed.title: Stuck at 33fps in SteamVR Games
embed.description:
If you're stuck at 33fps in SteamVR Games, follow these steps:

1. Completely close Steam and SteamVR.
2. Navigate to the following paths and delete these files:
    a. 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\SteamVR\resources\settings\default.vrsettings'
    b. 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\config\steamvr.vrsettings'
    c. 'C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\config\lighthouse\lighthousedb.json'

Next, uninstall SteamVR:
1. Right click the SteamVR tool from the Steam Library and select 'Uninstall'.
2. Follow the on-screen prompts to complete the uninstallation of the SteamVR tool.
3. Make sure to delete any leftover files in the installation directory by deleting the contents in the folder 'SteamVR'. The default path for that folder is '%ProgramFiles(x86)%\Steam\steamapps\common\SteamVR'.

Finally, reinstall SteamVR.

embed.title: Provide a TaskList
embed.description:
Open a command prompt as an Administrator on your computer and type: tasklist > C:\list.txt

Then, navigate to your C drive and attach the list.txt file here.

name: overlay
description: Sharing Screenshots of the Performance Overlay

embed.title: Sharing Screenshots of the Performance Overlay
embed.description:
1.) Go into the Settings tab in the Virtual Desktop menu in VR and ensure "copy screenshots to desktop" is enabled.
2.) Navigate to the Streaming tab and enable "Show performance overlay".
3.) Launch your VR game.
4.) Look for numbers that are turning orange.
5.) When you see this, hold the right Oculus button and press either the right or left trigger to take a screenshot.
If the screenshot shortcut does not work, press the Oculus button once and press the camera icon on the Oculus menu to take a screenshot.

On Pico Neo 3, press the Pico button on your controller, then click the screenshot (scissors) button.

On Pico 4, press the screenshot button on your right controller.

The screenshot will be found on your desktop, and you can share it here.

embed.title: Unable to Uninstall/Reinstall Streamer App
embed.description: If you're unable to uninstall or reinstall the Streamer App, you can use this [tool](https://download.vrdesktop.net/files/MicrosoftProgram_Install_and_Uninstall.meta.diagcab) for assistance.

name: connect
description: How to test if your PC and VR Headset can communicate

embed.title: How to test if your PC and VR Headset can communicate
embed.description:
To verify that your computer can communicate with your headset, note down the IP address of your headset, which is displayed at the top of the Computers tab in VR.
Once you have it, open a command prompt on your computer by clicking Start and typing: cmd
In the command prompt, type: ping x.x.x.x (where x.x.x.x is the IP address of your headset) and press Enter.
Then type: ipconfig and press Enter.
Share the results here.

name: windows
description: Guide to upgrade to Windows 10/11 while retaining files and apps

embed.title: Upgrade/Reinstall Windows 10/11 & Keep Your Files and Apps
embed.description:
Follow the below steps to upgrade or reinstall your Windows:

**Windows 10**:
1. Download the latest Windows 10 ISO from [Microsoft's website](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/software-download/windows10ISO).
2. Open the downloaded ISO.
3. Follow on-screen prompts and select 'Keep files and programs'.

Note: Always back up important data before an OS reinstall.

**Windows 11**:
1. Download the Windows 11 ISO from [Microsoft's website](https://www.microsoft.com/software-download/windows11).
2. Open the downloaded ISO.
3. Follow on-screen prompts and ensure to keep your data and applications.

Note: Ensure compatibility and back up important data before upgrading if you are on Windows 10.

name: download
description: How to manually update the Streamer app

embed.title: How to manually update the Streamer app
embed.description: To update, [download the Streamer from the website](https://www.vrdesktop.net/) and install it over the existing installation.

name: store
description: Can I Transfer My License When I Purchased on Store x?

embed.title: Purchasing Virtual Desktop
embed.description:
Virtual Desktop is available on supported headset's **official** stores. Since they're different stores from different companies, it needs to be purchased again if you bought it for one headset and not the other (cross-buy is not possible). It is compatible with multiple headsets released using the same store though, for example, if you bought Virtual Desktop for the Pico Neo 3 and then you buy the Pico 4, you do not need to purchase Virtual Desktop again. Same for if you purchase on the Meta store you can use it for Quest 1/2/3/Pro without repurchasing.

The app on each of the stores all have the same core features, allowing you to stream your desktop, videos, or PCVR games from your computer(s). The app is available in all markets, except for China.

**Do not** buy Virtual Desktop Classic on Steam, it is not intended for use with a standalone VR headset.

embed.title: Oculus Servers Unreachable
embed.description:
This could likely be a DNS issue or a bug associated with a recent Quest OS update. If your internet is working well from your Quest (you can check via store and web browser) and you've already rebooted your headset a few times, here are a few steps to try:

**Step 1:** You might want to change the assigned DNS in your router WAN settings (NOT LAN). This tends to be the quickest fix. We suggest using either 8.8.8.8 or 1.1.1.1, or both.

**Step 2:** Don't forget to reboot your router after making these changes. It's a small step that could make a big difference.

If all else fails, some users have resolved this issue by performing a factory reset on their Quest. However, be aware that this is due to a bug encountered with the recent Quest OS update, and this method may not work for everyone.

embed.title: Virtual Desktop False Positive
embed.description:
The Virtual Desktop installer might be flagged as suspicious by some antivirus programs. Don't worry, this is a false positive. The developer updated the AdvancedInstaller version, which can trigger some security alerts.

 The installer is safe and properly signed with Virtual Desktop's digital signature. You can safely proceed with the installation if you see any warnings.

embed.title: Virtual Desktop Repair
embed.description: If you are experiencing issues installing or updating Virtual Desktop, [please use this repair installer](https://download.vrdesktop.net/files/VirtualDesktop.Streamer.Repair.exe) to fix the problem.

embed.title: China Store
embed.description: Virtual Desktop is not available in China because it is impossible for us to provide support through the Great Firewall. It would require a separate cloud infrastructure, separate builds of the app and Streamer, etc. We do not have the team or the time for this.

embed.title: Half-Life: Alyx - Stutter Fix
embed.description: Right-click on Half-Life: Alyx in Steam, then click Properties. In the 'General' tab, click on 'Launch Options', and paste the following: ```+vr_fidelity_level_auto 0 +vr_fidelity_level 3```

footer.text: Check the /ics command for a guide on how to set up like the lower diagram

embed.title: Which codec should I use?
embed.description:
Best to leave the Preferred Codec to Automatic, but if you want to try different ones, here's which is best for what:

**H.264:** has the lowest latency but not as efficient as the other codecs
**H.264+:** has higher bitrate limit; good for racing or fast-paced games but requires ideal network conditions
**HEVC:** has improved efficiency (looks better at the same bitrate compared to H.264) but takes a bit more time to encode/decode
**AV1:** has best efficiency but requires Nvidia 4000 or AMD 7000 series GPU and a Quest 3
**10-bit encoding:** improves color gradients, recommended for darker/slower games

embed.title: Beat Saber Troubleshooting
embed.description:
Having stutters in Beat Saber? Try these changes to optimize your performance and reduce latency.

**For Beat Saber versions 1.30+**
- **Enable VDXR** in the Virtual Desktop PC Streamer App. This will bypass SteamVR and run Beat Saber with slightly more performance.

**For all other Beat Saber versions**
- **Adjust SteamVR render resolution** to Custom 100%. Ensure this applies to global and per-app Beat Saber settings in SteamVR.

**Beat Saber graphics options**
- **Reduce MSAA** to 2x (or disabled). In some cases, this will default to 4x or 8x and incur heavy performance penalties on most systems.
- **Adjust render scale** to 1.0. This ensures that Beat Saber is not supersampling your game, but rather rendering at your chosen Virtual Desktop resolution preset.

embed.title: Clean Reinstall SteamVR
embed.description:
**1).** Uninstall the Virtual Desktop Streamer app from Windows
**2).** Cleanly reinstall SteamVR using the [manual method](https://steamcommunity.com/app/250820/discussions/2/1640917625015598552/) or the [automated script](https://github.com/GeoMaciolek/steamvr-clean-reinstall)
**3).** Reinstall the [Virtual Desktop Streamer app](https://www.vrdesktop.net/)

embed.title: How to Launch External Games
embed.description:
**Method 1).** Once connected to your computer in VR, right-click the Virtual Desktop Streamer icon next to the clock at the bottom right of your screen and click `Launch game` then locate the executable of the game.

**Method 2).** Create a .bat file with the following content: `"C:\Program Files\Virtual Desktop Streamer\VirtualDesktop.Streamer.exe"` `[Path to game executable]` `[optional game arguments]`

Be aware that if you installed the Virtual Desktop Streamer elsewhere you will have to modify the location in the commands above.

name: stats
description: What the different latency figures mean

embed.title: Latency Figures in the Performace Overlay
embed.description:
**Game** is your computer's CPU/GPU rendering the game
**Encoding** is your GPU encoding the video
**Networking** is your router and network
**Decoding** is the headset GPU decoding the image

embed.title: Wireless Survey and Channel Allocation
embed.description:
For determining available channels on an Android device, [the open source version of Wifi Analyzer is the recommended app.](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.vrem.wifianalyzer) (Please avoid Ad supported imitations).

If you do not have an android phone but your pc has a WiFi adapter you can [use this application instead.](https://lizardsystems.com/wi-fi-scanner/)

For channel allocation reference, please see the image below:

embed.title: Windows Mobile Hotspots Are Not Supported
embed.description: We won't stop you from trying to use a Windows hotspot but we don't provide any support for setups that attempt to utilise them due to their inconsistency, unreliability, limitations and just because Windows performs poorly as a router/router replacement.

name: uh-oh
description: Your PC Isn't Connected by an Ethernet Cable?

embed.title: Your PC Isn't Connected by an Ethernet Cable?

name: about
description: Share the Details From Your About Tab

embed.title: Share the Details From Your About Tab
embed.description:
**1).** Share a screenshot of your About tab from the Virtual Desktop Streamer app installed on your PC. **Please do not crop the screenshot. The entire streamer window must be visible for support.**
**2).** Click "Check for Interfering Apps" and share a screenshot of the popup that appears here.

name: 6e
description: Do I need a Wifi 6E Router?

embed.title: Do I need a Wifi 6E Router?
embed.description:
If you have a lot of congestion at your location, it could help. Type /channels and hit enter in the chat here to see the channels list and a link to an Android tool for surveying the surrounding wifi.

**Is Wifi 6E FASTER than Wifi 6?**
No. The hardware for both wifi protocols are rated at the same speeds. HOWEVER, wifi 6E uses the 6Ghz band which is primarily not used by other devices and will not suffer from as much interference and congestion as Wifi 6 which should mean it performs better.
In the first image below I had two machines, both using Wifi 6 (5Ghz) and I was transferring a file between them. In the second image the exact same machines were connected to the same router with Wifi 6E (6Ghz). As you can see, the Wifi 6E connection was much more stable and nearly twice as fast because of a lack of interference!
Note: For some the 6Ghz band does not work as well over longer distances. Be sure your 6E router is in the room with your headset.

embed.title: Intel Driver and Support Assistant
embed.description: Make sure your Intel drivers are up-to-date by [clicking here](https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/support/intel-driver-support-assistant.html) to download and install the Intel Driver and Support Assistant.

name: usb
description: Virtual Desktop Does Not Support Streaming Over a USB Cable

embed.title: Virtual Desktop Does Not Support Streaming Over a USB Cable
embed.description: Third party store applications do not have low level access to the USB interface. We are aware that other solutions simulate a USB connection with alternative methods but these methods can not be supported by Virtual Desktop for PCVR game streaming.

name: runtimes
description: What is a "Runtime" and How Does it Relate to Virtual Desktop

embed.title: What is a "Runtime" and How Does it Relate to Virtual Desktop
embed.description: For a comprehensive explanation on what a "runtime" is and how it relates to Virtual Desktop, [please click here](https://github.com/mbucchia/VirtualDesktop-OpenXR/wiki/Oculus-%22Runtimes%22)

embed.title: SGSR (Snapdragon Game Super Resolution)
embed.description:
Qualcomm's SGSR (Snapdragon Game Super Resolution) implemented by Virtual Desktop is headset-side resolution upscaling performed on the headset after the video/image has been streamed from the PC.

The upscaling for each headset is as follows:

**Pico Neo 3, Pico 4, HTC Vive XR Elite and HTC Vive Focus 3:** Upscales to Ultra on settings up to High and 90Hz
**Quest 2, Quest Pro:** Only works on settings up to High and 90Hz
**Quest 3:** Works on all settings including Godlike 120Hz
**Quest 2, Quest Pro, Quest 3:** Upscales to the panel maximum

**SGSR not compatible with Chromakey Passthrough except on Quest 3. You will only be able to enable one or the other on all headsets other than Quest 3.**

name: support
description: Staff are only volunteers, please be respectful

embed.title: Staff are only volunteers, please be respectful
embed.description:
**Virtual Desktop support personnel are volunteers.** They will answer your questions based on their availability and the clarity of your request. Please be patient, courteous, clear and understand that there are limitations to their scope of support.'screen black how fix?' Will likely go unanswered. A complete question with detail will likely be answered.

Here are examples on how to ask questions with proper etiquette: [LINK](https://dontasktoask.com/)

name: installer
description: Streamer fails to install with installer not found error

embed.title: Streamer fails to install with installer not found error
embed.description:
If you are experiencing issues with installing or updating the streamer, try using the `Fix Problems Using Windows Update` option within windows recovery settings.

__It will NOT remove any personal files or applications__

name: spacewarp
description: Explanation on how Synchronous SpaceWarp functions

embed.title: Synchronous SpaceWarp
embed.description:
Synchronous SpaceWarp (SSW), developed in collaboration with Qualcomm, is Virtual Desktop's 3D **reprojection technology** designed to **halve the rendering load on PCs** by extrapolating every alternate frame directly on the headset. For instance, if your PC can only render **45fps**, the headset will fill in the gaps, keeping a smooth **90fps** experience.

SSW can introduce graphical **artifacts** that may appear as warping or straight lines bending, so if possible it's **preferable for your pc to render the full fps.** However SSW is **beneficial on lower end systems**, or when you want to **push higher graphical settings** than your PC is capable of normally.

This is **different** to PC technologies like DLSS 3 which ***interpolate*** frames as opposed to ***extrapolating*** frames. The difference being that **DLSS 3 increases latency** while **SSW reduces percieved latency**

embed.title: WRC Troubleshooting
embed.description:
**Jittering/stuttering**
- In the Virtual Desktop PC streamer app, change your OpenXR runtime selection to VDXR. This will bypass SteamVR and increase your performance and eliminate jittering/stuttering when moving your head.

**False/poor Controller Inputs**
- WRC accepts VR controllers as inputs, and thus Virtual Desktop's hand tracking feature can interfere with inputs even when holding a regular gamepad. Disable hand tracking in Virtual Desktop Input settings to avoid this conflict.

embed.title: Beta Feedback
embed.description: Questions, concerns or reports about issues involving the **BETA** should be addressed in the <#952979951286628362> channel.

name: avast
description: Avast Ruled as Spyware by FTC

embed.title: Avast Ruled as Spyware by FTC
embed.description: Avast was recently [sued by the FTC](https://consumer.ftc.gov/consumer-alerts/2024/02/software-provider-avast-will-pay-165-million-compromising-consumers-privacy) for selling private user data. We recommend removing Avast from your system, as it can now be considered spyware.

embed.title: Multi-Monitor
embed.description:
**Supported Headsets**
* **Meta Quest 3, Pico 4 Ultra:** Up to 3 monitors.
* **Meta Quest 2, Meta Quest Pro, Pico Neo 3, Pico 4, Vive Focus 3, Vive XR Elite:** Up to 2 monitors.
* **Meta Quest 1:** Only 1 monitor is supported

**Resolution Limits**
* **Meta Quest 3:**
 * **Single monitor:** Up to 3840x2160.
 * **Multiple monitors:** Up to 2560x1440 per monitor.
* **All other headsets:**
 * **Single monitor:** Up to 2560x1440.
 * **Multiple monitors:** Up to 1920x1080 per monitor.

**Streaming Quality**
The monitor stream has a maximum bitrate of 120mbps, shared between all active monitors:
* **1 monitor:** 120mbps
* **2 monitors:** 60mbps each
* **3 monitors:** 40mbps each

**Platform Specific**
**Windows:**
* Supports creating virtual monitors up to the maximum supported by your headset.
* You can mix both physical and virtual monitors (e.g., on Quest 3, you can have 2 physical monitors and 1 virtual monitor for a total of 3 monitors).

**MacOS:**
* The same monitor limits per headset apply as listed above.
* To create virtual monitors on macOS, you can use the free BetterDisplay app (https://betterdisplay.pro/).
 Create and enable the virtual monitors in that app, then restart your computer.
 When you are in VR, press the trigger while pointing below the screen and click 'Add monitor'

footer.text: Multi-Monitor support depends on PC Graphics power, multimonitor is automatically disabled when no hardware video encoder is present.

name: dongle
description: Connecting the Quest 3 directly with ethernet

embed.title: **__Using a USB Dongle/Adapter on your Quest 3__**
embed.description:
While it's **unsupported here and by Meta**, it is possible to use a USB to Ethernet adapter or hub attached to your Quest 3 headset.

There are a few conditions that must be met:
**1)** This is a not officially supported feature and can be removed by Meta at any time. (Meta removed this feature from the Quest 2 permanently and temporarily from the Quest 3 in the past)
**2)** Many USB to Ethernet devices simply will not work. You'll need to research which ones will work.
**3)** The USB to Ethernet device must be 1Gbps, Higher speeds are not supported by the headset.
**4)** The headset will give you no indication that it's using the Ethernet connection other than that it simply works.
**5)** **Neither Meta nor Virtual Desktop provide support for this feature. If it doesn't work properly, you'll need to do you own research to figure out why and how to fix it.**
